title: WHAT IS A STOCK?
bullet1: A stock represents ownership in a company
bullet2: When you buy a stock
bullet3: you're buying a piece of that business
bullet4: Think of a company as a whole pizza - owning a stock is like holding one slice
column9: It means you now own a part of the company and share in both the risks and the rewards

title: SHARES
bullet1: A share is one specific unit of ownership
bullet2: It tells you exactly how much of the company you own
bullet3: Think of a stock as a whole bar of chocolate - owning a share is like owning one square
bullet4: The more squares you have
column9: the more of the company you own

title: SUPPLY AND DEMAND
bullet1: There are only a finite amount of shares a company can have
bullet2: Stock prices are based on supply and demand
bullet3: When more people want to buy than sell
bullet4: prices go up
column9: When more people want to sell than buy

title: COMPANY
bullet1: A company is an organized business that sells products or services
bullet2: It can have employees
bullet3: managers
bullet4: and owners
column9: All work together to run operations and grow the business
column11: you become a partial owner of the company

title: OWNERSHIP BENEFITS
bullet1: Owning stock means you benefit when the company grows
bullet2: You also share in the risk if it fails
bullet3: Your ownership represents a piece of the company's future
bullet4: Potential rewards come with potential risks

title: IPO
bullet1: IPO stands for Initial Public Offering
bullet2: It's when a private company sells shares to the public for the first time
bullet3: Imagine a bakery opening its doors to the public for the first time
bullet4: The IPO is like that grand opening where people can buy slices (shares)

title: PUBLIC COMPANY
bullet1: A public company's shares are available to anyone on the stock market
bullet2: The general public can become part-owners by purchasing stock
bullet3: Shares are traded freely in the stock market
bullet4: Company value changes constantly based on market activity

title: PRIVATE COMPANY
bullet1: A private company is owned by a small group like founders or family
bullet2: Its shares are not available to the public
bullet3: Ownership is typically more concentrated
bullet4: Less regulatory requirements than public companies

title: IPO PURPOSE
bullet1: IPOs are a company's way of raising money from the public
bullet2: Companies exchange partial ownership for capital
bullet3: This money can be used for growth and expansion
bullet4: It's a major milestone in a company's development

title: PUBLIC TRADING
bullet1: Once a company goes public
bullet2: its shares trade freely
bullet3: Anyone can buy or sell shares on the stock market
bullet4: The company's value changes every second
column9: Market forces determine the stock price

title: DIVIDEND
bullet1: A dividend is money a company pays to shareholders from profits
bullet2: It's a way for the company to share earnings with owners
bullet3: Think of it like receiving a portion of the company's profits
bullet4: Not all companies pay dividends

title: DIVIDEND YIELD
bullet1: Dividend Yield is the percentage return from dividends relative to stock price
bullet2: Formula: (Annual Dividend per Share / Stock Price) × 100
bullet3: It helps compare dividend returns across different stocks
bullet4: A higher yield doesn't always mean better investment

title: CAPITAL GAINS
bullet1: Capital gains are profit from selling something for more than you paid
bullet2: For stocks
bullet3: it's the difference between buying and selling price
bullet4: You only realize capital gains when you sell
column9: They're one of two main ways to earn from stocks

title: EARNING FROM STOCKS
bullet1: You can earn from stocks in two main ways
bullet2: Dividend income from company profits
bullet3: Capital gains from selling at a higher price
bullet4: Some stocks offer both
column9: others offer neither

title: DIVIDEND POLICY
bullet1: Not all companies pay dividends
bullet2: Fast-growing companies often reinvest profits instead
bullet3: This can lead to higher stock prices over time
bullet4: Dividend policy reflects company strategy

title: STOCK VALUE
bullet1: Stock value depends on what investors believe the company is worth
bullet2: This includes current performance and future expectations
bullet3: Market sentiment can drive prices up or down
bullet4: Value is ultimately determined by supply and demand

title: MARKET CAP
bullet1: Market cap is the total value of a company's shares
bullet2: Calculate by multiplying share price by number of shares
bullet3: It tells you how "big" a company is in dollar terms
bullet4: Like comparing an ant to an elephant

title: LARGE-CAP VS. SMALL-CAP
bullet1: Large-cap companies have high market cap and are usually more stable
bullet2: Small-cap stocks may grow faster but are riskier
bullet3: Market cap helps categorize companies by size
bullet4: Different sizes have different risk/reward profiles

title: BOND
bullet1: A bond is like a loan you give to a company or government
bullet2: They promise to pay you interest regularly
bullet3: You get your money back on a set date
bullet4: It's generally considered safer than stocks

title: SECURITIES
bullet1: Securities are financial assets you can invest in
bullet2: They include stocks and bonds
bullet3: Stocks represent ownership
bullet4: bonds represent loans
column9: They're tradable financial instruments

title: STOCK EXCHANGE
bullet1: A stock exchange is where people buy and sell shares
bullet2: It's like a marketplace for stocks
bullet3: It helps people trade stocks safely and fairly
bullet4: Examples include NYSE and NASDAQ

title: TICKER SYMBOL
bullet1: A ticker symbol is a short code for a company's stock
bullet2: It helps quickly identify stocks on exchanges
bullet3: Examples: AAPL for Apple
bullet4: TSLA for Tesla
column9: They're usually 1-5 letters long

title: BROKER
bullet1: A broker helps you buy and sell stocks
bullet2: They act as the middleman between you and the exchange
bullet3: They provide the platform for trading
bullet4: You need a broker to access the stock market

title: BROKERAGE ACCOUNT
bullet1: A brokerage account is like a bank account for investing
bullet2: It holds your stocks
bullet3: bonds
bullet4: and other investments
column9: You need one to place trades
column10: It's required to participate in the stock market

title: BID-ASK SPREAD
bullet1: The bid is the highest price a buyer will pay
bullet2: The ask is the lowest price a seller will accept
bullet3: The spread is the difference between them
bullet4: It shows how much buyers and sellers disagree on price

title: EARNINGS PER SHARE
bullet1: EPS tells you how much profit a company makes per share
bullet2: Formula: (Net Income - Dividends) / Total Shares
bullet3: It helps understand company profitability
bullet4: Higher EPS usually means better performance

title: P/E RATIO
bullet1: P/E ratio shows how much investors pay for each dollar of earnings
bullet2: Formula: Share Price / EPS
bullet3: It helps determine if a stock is overpriced or underpriced
bullet4: Lower P/E often means better value

title: MARKET ORDER
bullet1: A market order executes immediately at the best available price
bullet2: You get the current market price
bullet3: It's the fastest way to buy or sell
bullet4: Price may vary slightly from what you see

title: LIMIT ORDER
bullet1: A limit order only executes at a specific price or better
bullet2: You set the maximum price you'll pay (or minimum you'll accept)
bullet3: It may not execute if the price doesn't reach your limit
bullet4: It gives you more control over price

title: STOCK INDEX
bullet1: A stock index is a group of stocks that represent a market or sector
bullet2: It shows the overall health of that market
bullet3: Examples include S&P 500 and Dow Jones
bullet4: When indices go up
column9: it usually means the market is doing well

title: STOCK INDEX PURPOSE
bullet1: Indices show the overall health of the market or a specific sector
bullet2: They help track market performance over time
bullet3: They provide a benchmark for comparison
bullet4: They can indicate economic trends

title: SECTOR
bullet1: A sector is a group of companies in the same industry
bullet2: Examples include technology
bullet3: healthcare
bullet4: and finance
column9: When sector indices move
column10: they show how that industry is performing

title: SECTOR PERFORMANCE
bullet1: When indices go up or down
bullet2: they give you a sense of how that part of the economy is doing
bullet3: Sector performance can indicate economic trends
bullet4: Different sectors perform differently at different times
column9: They help with investment decisions

title: BETA
bullet1: Beta measures how volatile a stock is compared to the market
bullet2: A beta of 1 means it moves with the market
bullet3: A beta above 1 means it's more volatile than the market
bullet4: A beta below 1 means it's less volatile

title: VOLATILITY
bullet1: Volatility is how much a stock's price changes over time
bullet2: High volatility means big price swings
bullet3: Low volatility means stable prices
bullet4: It's a measure of risk

title: RSI
bullet1: RSI (Relative Strength Index) measures if a stock is overbought or oversold
bullet2: Values range from 0 to 100
bullet3: Above 70 usually means overbought (might fall)
bullet4: Below 30 usually means oversold (might rise)

title: BULL/BEAR MARKETS
bullet1: A bull market is when prices are rising over time
bullet2: A bear market is when prices are falling over time
bullet3: Bull markets are optimistic
bullet4: bear markets are pessimistic
column9: They can last for months or years

title: EQUITY
bullet1: Equity means ownership in a company
bullet2: When you own stock
bullet3: you have equity in that company
bullet4: It represents your share of the company's value
column9: It's what's left after paying all debts

title: RETURN ON EQUITY
bullet1: ROE shows how efficiently a company uses shareholders' money
bullet2: It measures profit relative to shareholders' equity
bullet3: Higher ROE usually means better performance
bullet4: It helps compare companies

title: DEBT TO EQUITY
bullet1: Debt to Equity ratio compares a company's debt to its equity
bullet2: It shows how much debt the company uses to finance operations
bullet3: High ratios mean more debt relative to equity
bullet4: It's a measure of financial risk

title: LIQUIDITY
bullet1: Liquidity is how easily a stock can be bought or sold
bullet2: High liquidity means you can trade without affecting the price much
bullet3: Low liquidity means trading might move the price
bullet4: It's important for active traders

title: VOLUME
bullet1: Volume is the number of shares traded in a period
bullet2: High volume usually means lots of interest in the stock
bullet3: It can indicate the strength of price moves
bullet4: It's a key indicator for traders

title: VOLUME AND STOCK PRICES
bullet1: News
bullet2: earnings reports
bullet3: and global events can quickly change demand
bullet4: This affects trading volume and stock prices
column9: High volume often accompanies big price moves

title: CANDLESTICK
bullet1: A candlestick shows price movement over a time period
bullet2: The body shows opening and closing prices
bullet3: The wicks show highest and lowest prices
bullet4: Green means price went up
column9: red means it went down

title: 52W-HIGH/LOW
bullet1: 52W-High is the highest price in the past year
bullet2: 52W-Low is the lowest price in the past year
bullet3: The difference shows the stock's trading range
bullet4: It helps understand the stock's volatility

title: LONG POSITION
bullet1: A long position means you buy first and sell later
bullet2: You profit when the stock price goes up
bullet3: You believe the stock will rise in value
bullet4: It's the most common type of investment

title: SHORT POSITION
bullet1: A short position means you sell first and buy later
bullet2: You profit when the stock price goes down
bullet3: You borrow shares to sell them
bullet4: It's more complex and riskier than going long

title: LONG VS. SHORT
bullet1: Going long is like planting a seed and waiting for it to grow
bullet2: Going short is like selling fruit before you've picked it
bullet3: Long positions have limited risk
bullet4: short positions have unlimited risk
column9: Understanding both helps adapt to market conditions

title: SHORT POSITION RISK
bullet1: Shorting carries more risk than going long
bullet2: If the price keeps rising
bullet3: your losses can be unlimited
bullet4: You must eventually buy back the shares you borrowed
column9: It requires careful risk management

title: UNDERSTANDING LONG VS. SHORT
bullet1: Understanding long vs. short is key to adapting to both rising and falling markets
bullet2: Long positions benefit from price increases
bullet3: Short positions benefit from price decreases
bullet4: Both have their place in trading strategies

title: DAY TRADING
bullet1: Day trading means buying and selling stocks within the same day
bullet2: You don't hold positions overnight
bullet3: It requires speed
bullet4: discipline
column9: and constant attention

title: SWING TRADING
bullet1: Swing trading holds positions for days to weeks
bullet2: You capture medium-term price movements
bullet3: It's less intense than day trading
bullet4: It still requires active management

title: SCALPING
bullet1: Scalping is buying and selling stocks very quickly for small profits
bullet2: You make many small trades throughout the day
bullet3: It requires excellent timing and low transaction costs
bullet4: It's one of the most active trading styles

title: SHORT-TERM TRADING
bullet1: Short-term trading requires speed
bullet2: discipline
bullet3: and constant attention to news and charts
bullet4: You need to react quickly to market changes
column9: It's more time-intensive than long-term investing
column10: It can be very profitable but also very risky

title: MOVING AVERAGES
bullet1: Moving averages smooth out price data to show trends
bullet2: They help identify the direction of price movement
bullet3: Common periods are 50-day and 200-day
bullet4: They're widely used technical indicators

title: MACD
bullet1: MACD (Moving Average Convergence Divergence) is a momentum indicator
bullet2: It shows the relationship between two moving averages
bullet3: It helps identify trend changes and momentum
bullet4: It consists of a line
column9: signal line

title: TRUE RANGE/ATR
bullet1: True Range measures volatility
bullet2: ATR (Average True Range) is the average of true range over time
bullet3: It shows how much a stock typically moves
bullet4: It helps set stop-loss levels and position sizing

title: VWAP
bullet1: VWAP (Volume Weighted Average Price) is the average price weighted by trading volume
bullet2: It accounts for both price and volume
bullet3: It's more useful than a simple price average
bullet4: It's popular with institutional traders

title: SMA
bullet1: SMA (Simple Moving Average) is the average price over a period
bullet2: It smooths out price fluctuations
bullet3: It helps identify trends and support/resistance levels
bullet4: It's one of the most basic technical indicators

title: 5-DAY CHANGE PERCENTAGE
bullet1: 5-Day Change Percentage shows how much a stock has moved in 5 days
bullet2: It's calculated as: ((Current Price - Price 5 days ago) / Price 5 days ago) × 100
bullet3: It helps understand recent performance
bullet4: It's a common measure of short-term movement
